awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: The Role of Force, Flow, and Female Sex in Heart Development: Bicuspid Aortic Valve in Turner Syndrome
awd_abstract_narration:
This research will study how blood flow affects diseases of the heart and blood vessels differently in men and women. The work will lead to new treatments to improve nationwide health. One way to study how diseases affect women and men differently is to include people with Turner Syndrome. Like men, people with Turner Syndrome have only one X chromosome, but they are born with female features. The goal of this research is to identify X chromosome genes that regulate how heart valve cells respond to forces. This force response affects the development of the bicuspid aortic valve, and can create a birth defect. This problem is more common in men than in women, but is 50 times more common in people with Turner Syndrome. People with a bicuspid aortic valve and Turner Syndrome often need to have their aortic valves replaced at a relatively young age. Unfortunately, it is very hard to detect bicuspid aortic valve disease, even with imaging. This research will lead to new treatments for patients who need surgical valve replacement. A broad range of cardiovascular disease patients will benefit from these results, not only those with Turner Syndrome. This project will involve a collaboration between biomedical engineers, geneticists, and cardiologists. The research team will educate the Turner Syndrome community about bioengineering and the research. By training graduate, undergraduate, and high school students, this project will broaden participation of underrepresented groups in research. It will also advance discovery and understanding while promoting teaching, training, and learning.

X chromosome dosage is a novel regulatory factor for endothelial to mesenchymal transformation. Understanding this novel aspect of cell mechanobiology will be broadly relevant to sexually dimorphic development and disease.  This research will address how regulation of endothelial to mesenchymal transformation is involved in bicuspid aortic valve development and fibrocalcific changes of bicuspid valves in adults. Using cells from Turner Syndrome patients, the research team will quantify a role for X chromosome dosage in mechanical regulation of this transformation by controlling the microenvironment, exogenous mechanical stimuli, and patient-specific characteristics. Finally, inducible transgenic approaches will be used to correct X chromosome gene expression and reverse the transformation defects. This data will provide transformational new information on the role of X chromosome genes and their mechanobiology in bicuspid aortic valves and identify new therapeutic targets for related diseases that affect millions of patients.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit:

This research focuses on understanding how certain genetic and environmental factors contribute to diseases in the heart, particularly in people with Turner Syndrome (TS), a condition where one of the X chromosomes is missing or altered. One of the key issues we studied is how the behavior of endothelial cells (the cells lining blood vessels) can lead to fibrocalcific valve disease, a condition where the heart's valves become stiff and can no longer work properly. We looked at the role of X chromosome abnormalities, as well as how mechanical forces like blood flow and tissue stiffness can influence disease development.

One of our main goals was to explore how changes in the X chromosome might contribute to a process called endothelial to mesenchymal transition (endMT). EndMT is a process where healthy endothelial cells change into a different cell type that can promote disease. We worked with two types of cells: human aortic endothelial cells (HAECs) and porcine aortic valve endothelial cells (PAVECs), using these as control groups to compare to endothelial cells derived from people with Turner Syndrome. We applied shear stress (force from blood flow) to see how it affected the cells. We also used hydrogels to mimic the stiffness and breakdown properties of heart tissues.

Key takeaways from our studies:

Shear stress: Valve endothelial cells respond to mechanical forces (like blood flow) by changing their behavior. These changes can lead to inflammation, oxidative stress, and endMT, all of which contribute to the development of heart valve diseases.

Hydrogel systems: The use of hydrogels allowed us to create environments that mimic the stiffness and degradation properties of heart valve tissues. This was crucial for studying how endothelial cells respond in different conditions that they might encounter in the body.

Sex-specific differences: We developed male and female cell lines to see if there were any differences in how cells of different sexes responded to shear stress. This could help explain why some heart diseases affect men and women differently. We found that that male valve endothelial cells were much more responsive to mechanical stimulation through shear stress compared with female control cells. Endothelial cells derived from Turner Syndrome patients were highly sensitive to shear stress in some ways, but surprisingly these cells did not change their direction when they were treated with shear stress. In other words, they did not show the expected characteristic behavior of valve endothelial cells.

In conclusion, by studying endothelial cells in controlled lab environments, we are gaining insights that could lead to new ways to prevent and treat diseases like fibrocalcific valve disease. Future research will focus on refining these methods and exploring gene-editing treatments for conditions like Turner Syndrome.

Broader Impacts:

This research has several important impacts across different fields. In the primary discipline of mechanobiology, it has advanced our understanding of how genetic factors, like X chromosome dosage, and mechanical forces, like shear stress and substrate stiffness, influence heart valve cells. This is particularly relevant to developing tissue-engineered heart valves and understanding vascular diseases such as aortic valve disease and pulmonary hypertension. The study has also shed light on the sex-specific responses of heart valve endothelial cells to mechanical stimuli, which could lead to new insights into diseases that affect men and women differently, such as bicuspid aortic valve disease (BAV) and thoracic aortic dissection.

In other disciplines, this research opens new directions in understanding how biophysical factors impact various tissues and diseases, including cancer, cardiovascular conditions, and musculoskeletal diseases. It has also contributed to human resource development by involving undergraduate and high school students in research, fostering education in bioengineering and genetics.

Additionally, the project has enhanced infrastructure, creating new shear stress bioreactors that can be used for broader research, and improved resources like flow cytometry and PCR equipment. The molecular data generated will be valuable for future research on heart development and disease, potentially leading to new therapies for diseases like BAV. This research also engaged the Turner Syndrome community, offering both scientific and educational outreach.
